CE.description: Since CE → CO, if CNF cannot support CO in polynomial time, it cannot support CE in polynomial time either.

CT.description: Since CT → CO, if CNF cannot support CO in polynomial time, it cannot support CT in polynomial time either.

EQ.description: Since EQ → CO, if CNF cannot support CO in polynomial time, it cannot support EQ in polynomial time either.

SE.description: Since SE → EQ, if CNF cannot support EQ in polynomial time, it cannot support SE in polynomial time either.

CE.description: cSDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore cSDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since cSDD supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

CE.description: d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore d-DNNF supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since d-DNNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. If d-DNNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore d-DNNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: d-SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore d-SDNNF supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since d-SDNNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time. If d-SDNNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore d-SDNNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore DNF supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since DNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

CT.description: Since CT → VA, if DNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support CT in polynomial time either.

EQ.description: Since EQ → VA, if DNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support EQ in polynomial time either.

IM.description: Since IM → VA, if DNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support IM in polynomial time either.

SE.description: Since SE → EQ, if DNF cannot support EQ in polynomial time, it cannot support SE in polynomial time either.

CE.description: DNNF supports clause entailment (CE) in polynomial time (Darwiche, 2001a).

CO.description: Since DNNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

CT.description: Since CT → VA, if DNNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support CT in polynomial time either.

EQ.description: Since EQ → VA, if DNNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support EQ in polynomial time either.

IM.description: Since IM → VA, if DNNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support IM in polynomial time either.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. If DNNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore DNNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

VA.description: DNF does not support VA in polynomial time, and DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. If DNNF supported VA in polynomial time, then DNF could too by transforming first. Therefore DNNF does not support VA in polynomial time.

CE.description: FBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore FBDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: It is well-known that FBDD satisfies CO \citet{Gergov_1994, Darwiche_2002}. Consistency is polynomial: check if the BDD root is not the terminal 0 node.

CT.description: It is well-known that FBDD satisfies CT \citet{Gergov_1994, Darwiche_2002}. Model counting on FBDDs can be done in polynomial time by a single bottom-up pass counting satisfying assignments at each node.

EQ.description: Unlike OBDDs, FBDDs are not canonical, so equivalence checking is not straightforward. The complexity of EQ for FBDDs requires further investigation.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. If FBDD supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore FBDD does not support SE in polynomial time.

VA.description: It is well-known that FBDD satisfies VA \citet{Gergov_1994, Darwiche_2002}. Validity is polynomial: check if the BDD root equals the terminal 1 node.

CE.description: IP transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore IP supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since IP supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

CE.description: MODS transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore MODS supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: A sentence $\Sigma$ is consistent iff it has at least one model. The number of models of $\Sigma$ is given by the number of edges outgoing from the or-node in any MODS representation of $\Sigma$. Accordingly, CO can be achieved in polynomial time by checking if this count is nonzero (Table 18, Darwiche 2002).

CT.description: The number of models of $\Sigma$ is given by the number of edges outgoing from the or-node in any MODS representation of $\Sigma$. Accordingly, CT (model counting) can be achieved in polynomial time by counting these edges (Table 18, Darwiche 2002).

EQ.description: MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time, and OBDD$_<$ supports EQ in polynomial time. Therefore MODS supports EQ in polynomial time.

IM.description: MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time, and OBDD$_<$ supports IM in polynomial time. Therefore MODS supports IM in polynomial time.

ME.description: MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time, and OBDD$_<$ supports ME in polynomial time. Therefore MODS supports ME in polynomial time.

SE.description: MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time, and OBDD$_<$ supports SE in polynomial time. Therefore MODS supports SE in polynomial time.

VA.description: A sentence $\Sigma$ is valid iff it has $2^n$ models, where $n = |\text{Vars}(\Sigma)|$. The number of models of $\Sigma$ is given by the number of edges outgoing from the or-node in any MODS representation of $\Sigma$. Accordingly, VA can be achieved in polynomial time by checking if this count equals $2^n$ (Table 18, Darwiche 2002).

CE.description: nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore nFBDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since nFBDD supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. If nFBDD supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore nFBDD does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: Since CE → CO, if NNF cannot support CO in polynomial time, it cannot support CE in polynomial time either.

CO.description: CNF does not support CO in polynomial time, and CNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. If NNF supported CO in polynomial time, then CNF could too by transforming first. Therefore NNF does not support CO in polynomial time.

CT.description: Since CT → CO, if NNF cannot support CO in polynomial time, it cannot support CT in polynomial time either.

EQ.description: Since EQ → CO, if NNF cannot support CO in polynomial time, it cannot support EQ in polynomial time either.

IM.description: Since IM → VA, if NNF cannot support VA in polynomial time, it cannot support IM in polynomial time either.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to NNF in polynomial time. If NNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore NNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

VA.description: DNF does not support VA in polynomial time, and DNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. If NNF supported VA in polynomial time, then DNF could too by transforming first. Therefore NNF does not support VA in polynomial time.

CE.description: nOBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore nOBDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since nOBDD supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time. If nOBDD supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore nOBDD does not support SE in polynomial time.

languages.fullName: Ordered Binary Decision Diagram (wrt a fixed variable order)
languages.name: OBDD$_<$

CO.description: Consistency is trivial for OBDDs: check if the diagram root is not the terminal 0 node \citet{Bryant_1986}.

CT.description: Model counting on OBDDs can be done in polynomial time by a single bottom-up pass \citet{Bryant_1986, Bryant_1992}.

EQ.description: OBDDs with a fixed variable ordering are canonical: two functions are equivalent iff their reduced OBDDs are identical. This makes EQ trivial (structural isomorphism check) \citet{Bryant_1986, Bryant_1992, Meinel_Theobald_1998} (Theorem 8.11).

VA.description: Validity is trivial for OBDDs: check if the diagram root equals the terminal 1 node \citet{Bryant_1986}.

languages.definition: Ordered Binary Decision Diagram with respect to a fixed variable order

CE.description: SDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore SDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since SDD supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time. If SDD supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore SDD does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore SDNNF supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since SDNNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time. If SDNNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore SDNNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: uFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore uFBDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since uFBDD supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time. If uFBDD supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore uFBDD does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: uOBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore uOBDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since uOBDD supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time. If uOBDD supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore uOBDD does not support SE in polynomial time.

CE.description: OBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore OBDD supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Any query concerning OBDD is equivalent to the corresponding query concerning OBDD$_<$ when only one DAG is involved. Since OBDD$_<$ satisfies CO, VA and CT, so does OBDD \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

CT.description: Any query concerning OBDD is equivalent to the corresponding query concerning OBDD$_<$ when only one DAG is involved. Since OBDD$_<$ satisfies CO, VA and CT, so does OBDD \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SE.description:
Checking sentential entailment for OBDD formulas is coNP-complete. Since OBDD satisfies $
eg$C and since $\alpha \land  eta$ is consistent iff $\alpha 
ot\models 
eg eta$, checking SE for OBDD is coNP-complete (Lemma 8.14, Meinel \& Theobald 1998). This is because checking consistency of two OBDD$_<$ formulas with different variable orderings is NP-complete.

VA.description: Any query concerning OBDD is equivalent to the corresponding query concerning OBDD$_<$ when only one DAG is involved. Since OBDD$_<$ satisfies CO, VA and CT, so does OBDD \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

CE.description: dec-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore dec-DNNF supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since dec-DNNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

CT.description: dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasi-polynomial time, and FBDD supports CT. Therefore dec-DNNF supports CT in at most quasi-polynomial time.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time. If dec-DNNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore dec-DNNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

VA.description: dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasi-polynomial time, and FBDD supports VA. Therefore dec-DNNF supports VA in at most quasi-polynomial time.

CE.description: dec-SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time, and DNNF supports CE in polynomial time. Therefore dec-SDNNF supports CE in polynomial time.

CO.description: Since dec-SDNNF supports CE, it also supports CO. CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

CT.description: dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in quasi-polynomial time, and FBDD supports CT. Therefore dec-SDNNF supports CT in at most quasi-polynomial time.

SE.description: OBDD does not support SE in polynomial time, and OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time. If dec-SDNNF supported SE in polynomial time, then OBDD could too by transforming first. Therefore dec-SDNNF does not support SE in polynomial time.

VA.description: dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in quasi-polynomial time, and FBDD supports VA. Therefore dec-SDNNF supports VA in at most quasi-polynomial time.

references.bibtex:
@article{Selman_1996,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable form—allowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193–224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

references.bibtex:
@inproceedings{Darwiche_2011,
author = {Darwiche, Adnan},
title = {SDD: a new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases},
year = {2011},
isbn = {9781577355144},
publisher = {AAAI Press},
abstract = {We identify a new representation of propositional knowledge bases, the Sentential Decision Diagram (SDD), which is interesting for a number of reasons. First, it is canonical in the presence of additional properties that resemble reduction rules of OBDDs. Second, SDDs can be combined using any Boolean operator in polytime. Third, CNFs with n variables and treewidth w have canonical SDDs of size O(n2w), which is tighter than the bound on OBDDs based on pathwidth. Finally, every OBDD is an SDD. Hence, working with the latter does not preclude the former.},
booktitle = {Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Volume Two},
pages = {819–826},
numpages = {8},
location = {Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain},
series = {IJCAI'11}
}
references.title: A. Darwiche, "SDD: a new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases," Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Volume Two, pp. 819–826, 2011.

references.bibtex: @article{Van den Broeck_Darwiche_2015, title={On the Role of Canonicity in Knowledge Compilation}, volume={29}, url={https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/AAAI/article/view/9423}, DOI={10.1609/aaai.v29i1.9423}, abstractNote={ <p> Knowledge compilation is a powerful reasoning paradigm with many applications across AI and computer science more broadly. We consider the problem of bottom-up compilation of knowledge bases, which is usually predicated on the existence of a polytime function for combining compilations using Boolean operators (usually called an Apply function). While such a polytime Apply function is known to exist for certain languages (e.g., OBDDs) and not exist for others (e.g., DNNFs), its existence for certain languages remains unknown. Among the latter is the recently introduced language of Sentential Decision Diagrams (SDDs): while a polytime Apply function exists for SDDs, it was unknown whether such a function exists for the important subset of compressed SDDs which are canonical. We resolve this open question in this paper and consider some of its theoretical and practical implications. Some of the findings we report question the common wisdom on the relationship between bottom-up compilation, language canonicity and the complexity of the Apply function. </p> }, number={1}, journal={Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence}, author={Van den Broeck, Guy and Darwiche, Adnan}, year={2015}, month={Feb.} }
references.title: G. Van den Broeck and A. Darwiche, "On the Role of Canonicity in Knowledge Compilation," Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, vol. 29, 2015.

references.bibtex: @article{Bova_2016_a, title={SDDs Are Exponentially More Succinct than OBDDs}, volume={30}, url={https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/AAAI/article/view/10107}, DOI={10.1609/aaai.v30i1.10107}, abstractNote={ <p> Introduced by Darwiche (2011), sentential decision diagrams (SDDs) are essentially as tractable as ordered binary decision diagrams (OBDDs), but tend to be more succinct in practice. This makes SDDs a prominent representation language, with many applications in artificial intelligence and knowledge compilation. We prove that SDDs are more succinct than OBDDs also in theory, by constructing a family of boolean functions where each member has polynomial SDD size but exponential OBDD size. This exponential separation improves a quasipolynomial separation recently established by Razgon (2014), and settles an open problem in knowledge compilation (Darwiche, 2011). </p> }, number={1}, journal={Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence}, author={Bova, Simone}, year={2016}, month={Feb.} }
references.title: S. Bova, "SDDs Are Exponentially More Succinct than OBDDs," Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, vol. 30, 2016.

references.bibtex:
@article{Sauerhoff_2003,
title = {Approximation of boolean functions by combinatorial rectangles},
journal = {Theoretical Computer Science},
volume = {301},
number = {1},
pages = {45-78},
year = {2003},
issn = {0304-3975},
doi = {https://doi.org/10.1016/S0304-3975(02)00568-6},
url = {https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304397502005686},
author = {Martin Sauerhoff},
keywords = {Branching programs, Communication complexity, Lower bounds, Approximation, Nondeterminism, Randomness},
abstract = {This paper deals with the number of monochromatic combinatorial rectangles required to approximate a boolean function on a constant fraction of all inputs, where each rectangle may use its own partition of the input variables. The main result of the paper is that the number of rectangles required for the approximation of boolean functions in this model is very sensitive to the allowed error. There is an explicitly defined sequence of boolean functions fn on n variables such that fn has rectangle approximations with a constant number of rectangles and one-sided error 13+o(1) or two-sided error 14+o(1), but, on the other hand, fn requires exponentially many rectangles if the error bounds are decreased by an arbitrarily small constant. As applications of this result, the following separation results for read-once branching programs are obtained. The functions from the main result require only linear size for nondeterministic read-once branching programs and randomized read-once branching programs with two-sided error 13+o(1), while randomized read-once branching programs with constant two-sided error smaller than 13 and unambiguous nondeterministic read-once branching programs require exponential size.}
}
references.title: Martin Sauerhoff, "Approximation of boolean functions by combinatorial rectangles," Theoretical Computer Science, vol. 301, pp. 45-78, 2003.

matrix.description: PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. cSDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

d-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

MODS transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $CNF$ is a subset of $NNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

nOBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
It is well-known that some $CNF$ formulas (i.e. $\neg PARITY_n=\neg\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicants.

SDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

uOBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that CNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to d-DNNF.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to d-SDNNF.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to DNNF.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to nFBDD.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to NNF.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to nOBDD.
As defined by \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}, $cSDD$ is the compressed subset of $SDD$, so transformation is trivial.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to SDNNF.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to uFBDD.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from cSDD to uOBDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. cSDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, d-DNNF is a subset of DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

$d$-$DNNF$s can polynomially represent the disjunction of two functions with conflicting variable orders, which forces $FBDD$s to grow exponentially to track the state of both orders within a single "read-once" path.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $d-DNNF$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

noPolyDescription.description: dec-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.
d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to NNF.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If d-DNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If d-DNNF transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: The quasi-polynomial compilation from $dec$-$DNNF$ to $FBDD$ yields a $uFBDD$ when applied to a $d$-$DNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
The quasi-polynomial compilation from $dec$-$DNNF$ to $FBDD$ yields a $uFBDD$ when applied to a $d$-$DNNF$.

uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
Shown by Corollary 3.5 of \citet{Beame_2013}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

cSDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If d-SDNNF transforms to cSDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to SDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Vinall-Smeeth_2024}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $d$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $d$-$DNNF$, so transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to DNNF.

dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. FBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-SDNNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-SDNNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

If d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Suppose not; then $\forall\Lambda\in DNF$, $\exists$ an equivalent $\Lambda_*\in d$-$DNNF$ of polynomial size. Then we may perform a clausal entailment check on some $CNF$ sentence $\Sigma \in CNF$ with respect to some clause $\gamma$ by checking whether $(\neg\Sigma\vee\gamma)\in DNF$ is valid. But we may perform a validity check on $(\neg\Sigma\vee\gamma)_* \in d$-$DNNF$ in polynomial time. Since we can now perform a polynomial-time clausal entailment check on all $CNF$ sentences, the polynomial hierarchy collapses.

Recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the (not necessarily disjoint) rewirings of the nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and a 1-edge. We note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$ gates are decomposable. Furthermore, $\vee$ gates are only introduced in the rewriting, so we obtain a $dec$-$DNNF$ in linear time.

Consider the $DNF$ formula $\Pi_n= igvee_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicants form and each clause in $\Pi_n$ is an essential prime implicant of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Pi_n\in IP$.

Since the early work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicates of a formula is a lower bound on the number of clauses that can be found in any $CNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, $
eg\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, so any $CNF$ representation of $
eg\Pi_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).

eg\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}	o\{0,1\}$ so $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=0 \iff I 	ext{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. This is the negation of the clique detection function. However, it can be shown that $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicates, which implies that not every $IP$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.

Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable, so we attain a $DNNF$.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$.

Any $DNF$ can be represented as an $nOBDD$ in linear time; however the family of $DNF$s $(\phi_n)_{n\in\N}$ built from expander graphs have treewidth linear in their size. Thus, any $uOBDD$ for $\phi_n$ is of size $2^{\Omega(|\phi_n|)}$.

If nOBDD transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If nOBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.
$PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$ has linear size $OBDD_<$ representations but only exponential size $CNF$ representations.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to d-DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to d-SDNNF.
$PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$ has linear size $OBDD_<$ representations but only exponential size $DNF$ representations.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to FBDD.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD$_<$ transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD$_<$ transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to nFBDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to NNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to nOBDD.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD$_<$ transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2011}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to SDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to SDNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to uFBDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to uOBDD.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD_<$ is a subset of $OBDD$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to dec-DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to dec-SDNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $PI$ is a subset of $CNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

cSDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If PI transforms to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

d-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

Consider the $CNF$ formula $\Sigma_n= igwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicates form and each clause in $\Sigma_n$ is an essential prime implicate of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Sigma_n\in PI$.

Since the work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicants of a formula is a lower bound on the number of terms that can be found in any $DNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, $
eg\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, so any $DNF$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
Proposition 11 of \citet{Bova_2016} shows that the $JS_n$ has $PI$ size $O(n^2)$. Proposition 12 of \citet{Bova_2016} shows that $JS_n$ has $DNNF$ size $2^{\Omega(n^2)}$.

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. This is the clique detection function. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. However, it can be shown that $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicants, and hence not every $PI$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If PI transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $PI$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.
PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. CNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from PI to NNF.

nOBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

uOBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. If SDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to d-DNNF.
$SDD$ is a strict subset of $d$-$SDNNF$.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. If SDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to nFBDD.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to NNF.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to nOBDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then SDD transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that SDD cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bryant_1986,Bova_2016_a}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to SDNNF.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to uFBDD.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to uOBDD.
$OBDD$ representations of $HWB_n$ are $2^{\Omega(n)}$\citet{Bryant_1986}, but an $SDD$ can represent $HWB_n$ in size $O(n^3)$\citet{Bova_2016_a}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then SDD transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that SDD cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bryant_1986,Bova_2016_a}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a structured $DNNF$ is a triple of the corresponding $DNNF$, the v-tree $T$, and a mapping $\rho$; as such, extracting a $DNNF$ from a $SDNNF$ is trivial.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

quasiDescription.description: SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to nFBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to nFBDD.
SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to NNF.

noPolyDescription.description: d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

quasiDescription.description: Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If SDNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018,Van den Broeck_2015}.

The transformation is in fact linear. We may recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee(\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewiring of nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and 1-edge. Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable; furthermore, all $\vee$-gates in the rewiring are deterministic, so we attain a $d$-$DNNF$.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uFBDD to DNNF.

Consider the Boolean functions $\phi_n, \psi_n: \{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$, which respectively test whether, in an $n\times n$ Boolean matrix, that the number of 1's is odd and there is a row full of 1's, and that the number of 1's is even and there is a column full of 1's. \citet{Bova_2016} and \citet{Wegener_2000} show that an $FBDD$ expression for $\phi_n \vee \psi_n$ has necessarily size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$; but since an $FBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ may test $\phi_n$ or $\psi_n$ separately (shown by Proposition 3.1 of \citet{Amarilli_2018}), a $uFBDD$ for $\phi_n\vee \psi_n$ may be obtained by simply adding an $\vee$-gate joining these two $FBDD$ expressions, since $\phi_n \wedge \psi_n$ is unsatisfiable.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uFBDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
As defined by "Connecting Knowledge Compilation Classes and Width Parameters," $uFBDD$ is the subset of $nFBDD$ satisfying unambiguity.

uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uFBDD to NNF.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.
