This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uFBDD transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If uFBDD transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uFBDD transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2000}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uOBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to d-DNNF.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$. Since $D$ is unambiguous, for every rewritten node the two subcircuits $(x \wedge D_0)$ and $(\neg x \wedge D_1)$ are mutually exclusive, ensuring that all $\vee$-gates introduced in the translation are deterministic. The resulting circuit is therefore a deterministic structured DNNF (d-SDNNF), and the compilation remains linear-time.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uOBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to DNNF.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uOBDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uOBDD transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to nFBDD.

uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to NNF.
As defined by "Connecting Knowledge Compilation Classes and Width Parameters," $uOBDD$ is the subset of $nOBDD$ satisfying unambiguity.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uOBDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uOBDD transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to SDNNF.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $uOBDD$ is the subset of $uFBDD$ satisfying an order of the variables.
$uOBDD$ can have polynomial size for $HWB_n$, but $OBDD$s have size $2^\Omega(n)$

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If uOBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to d-DNNF.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to d-SDNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to DNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD$ is a superset of $FBDD$. Therefore a polynomial time transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to nFBDD.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to NNF.
OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to nOBDD.

The function $\bigwedge_{i=1}^n(x_i\Leftrightarrow y_i)$ has an $OBDD_<$ representation of size polynomial in $n$ whenever $<$ satisfies $x_1<y_1<...<x_n<y_n$ but exponential in $n$ if $<$ satisfies $x_1<x_2<...<x_n<y_1<y_2<...<y_n$

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If OBDD transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
Every $OBDD$ is a right-linear $SDD$; $SDD$ generalizes $OBDD$.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to SDNNF.
OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to uFBDD.
As defined by "Connecting Knowledge Compilation Classes and Width Parameters," $OBDD$ is the subset of $uOBDD$ without any $\vee$-node.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to dec-DNNF.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$. Since $D$ is unambiguous, for every rewritten node the two subcircuits $(x \wedge D_0)$ and $(\neg x \wedge D_1)$ are mutually exclusive, ensuring that all $\vee$-gates introduced in the translation are deterministic. The resulting circuit is therefore a deterministic structured DNNF (d-SDNNF), and the compilation remains linear-time.  In the case of an OBDD, all disjunctions in the resulting circuit arise from the rewriting of decision nodes, so every $\vee$-gate is a decision gate. Combined with the structured decomposability ensured by the $v$-tree, this yields a dec-SDNNF. The translation is linear in the size of $D$.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $dec$-$DNNF$ is the subset of $d$-$DNNF$ satisfying the decision property.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from dec-DNNF to DNNF.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If dec-DNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If dec-DNNF transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Beame_2013}. FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from dec-DNNF to uFBDD.

quasiDescription.description: Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $dec$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $dec$-$DNNF$, so discarding the v-tree completes the transformation.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where given each pair $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one of must be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise DNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Pi_n = \bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where after pairing $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one pair must have both be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise CNF.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.

separatingFunctions.name: Clique Detection Instances
separatingFunctions.description: Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$.

separatingFunctions.name: Sauerhoff function
separatingFunctions.description: Let $g_n: \{0,1\}^{2n} \to \{0,1\}$ be the function evaluating to 1 if and only if the sum of its inputs is divisible by 3. The Sauerhoff function $S_n: \{0,1\}^{n^2} \to \{0,1\}$ is defined on the $n \times n$ matrix $X = (x_{i,j})$ as $S_n(X) = R_n(X) \vee C_n(X)$, where $R_n, C_n : \{0,1\}^{n^2} \to \{0,1\}$ are defined by $R_n(X) = \bigplus_{i=1}^n g_n(x_{i1},x_{i2},...,x_{in}$ and $C_n(X) = R_n(X^T)$.

separatingFunctions.name: Jukna-Schnitger function
separatingFunctions.description: Let $K_n$ be the set of all 2-element subsets of $\{1,...,n\}$. Let the graph $G \subset K_n$ be encoded by the $\{0,1\}$ assignment of $K_n$ mapping a variable to 1 if and only if it is in the edge set of $G$. A triangle is defined as the edges $\{i, j\}, \{j, k\}, \{k, i\}$, where $i, j, k$ are distinct. Let $T_n$ be the set of all triangles on $n$ vertices. Let $JS_n^A: \{0,1\}^{K_n}\to\{0,1\}$ be the function accepting exactly those graphs over $\{1,...,n\}$ that avoid all triangles in $A$. \citet{Jukna_2002} show that for every $n$ there exists an $A_n \subset T_n$ of size $O(n^2)$ so that any balanced rectangle cover of $JS_n^{A_n}$ has size $2^{\Omega(n^2)}$. Call this function $JS_n$ the Jukna-Schnitger function.

operationLemmas.description: CO and CD imply ME: First test consistency (polytime via CO). If inconsistent, return the empty set. Otherwise, build a decision tree of models by iterating over variables $x_1, \ldots, x_n$ and using CD to test consistency of $\Sigma | \alpha \land x_i$ and $\Sigma | \alpha \land \neg x_i$ for each leaf term $\alpha$. Since one branch must succeed for consistent terms, the tree has $O(mn)$ tests where $m$ is the model count and $n$ is the variable count.
CO and CD imply CE: To test whether sentence $\Sigma$ entails non-valid clause $\alpha$, i.e. $\Sigma \models \alpha$, it suffices to test whether $\Sigma | \neg\alpha$ is inconsistent.

VA and CD imply IM: To test whether consistent term $\alpha$ entails sentence $\Sigma$, i.e. $\alpha \models \Sigma$, test whether $
eg\alpha \lor \Sigma$ is valid. This is equivalent to $
eg\alpha \lor (\Sigma | \alpha)$. Since $
eg\alpha$ and $\Sigma | \alpha$ share no variables, the disjunction is valid iff $
eg\alpha$ is valid or $\Sigma | \alpha$ is valid. Since $\alpha$ is consistent, $
eg\alpha$ cannot be valid. Thus we test validity of $\Sigma | \alpha$, constructible in polytime via CD and testable in polytime via VA.
EQ implies CO: $\mathsf{true}$ and $\mathsf{false}$ belong to every NNF subset. $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff it is equivalent to $\mathsf{false}$.
EQ implies VA: $\mathsf{true}$ and $\mathsf{false}$ belong to every NNF subset. $\Sigma$ is valid iff it is equivalent to $\mathsf{true}$.
SE implies EQ: Sentences $\Sigma_1$ and $\Sigma_2$ are equivalent iff $\Sigma_1 \models \Sigma_2$ and $\Sigma_2 \models \Sigma_1$.
CT implies CO: Model counting (CT) requires enumerating all satisfying assignments. If a formula is inconsistent, it has zero models. Thus CT can determine CO by checking if the model count is zero.
CT implies VA: A formula is valid iff all $2^n$ assignments satisfy it. If we can count models in polytime (CT), we can check validity by testing if the count equals $2^n$.

IM implies VA: A formula $\Sigma$ is valid iff the complete term (all positive or all negative literals, i.e., any single model) implies $\Sigma$. Since IM tests whether a consistent term implies the sentence, testing with a trivially consistent term gives validity.
CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.
